abstract.p: A slotted disc spring consists of two segments: a coned disc segment and a number of lever arm segments. In this study, a load–displacement formula for the slotted disc spring is newly developed in the form of energy method by considering both rigid and bending deflections of the two segments. This formula is developed with the aim to further improve the SAE formula which is limited to a straight slotted disc spring. The coned and the lever arm angles of the straight slotted disc spring are the same. They are different for a bended slotted disc spring. Because of this limitation, it is geometrically impractical to employ the SAE formula for a bended slotted disc spring. To achieve the goal of this study, new calculations based on geometric and material properties inputs are developed for a bended slotted disc spring. A firm background study based on the theory of Almen is presented in developing new load–displacement calculations for a bended slotted disc spring.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Disc spring is well known for its configuration to non-linearly withstand a large force with minimum deflection while storing a large amount of energy in relation to the space occupied. The analysis of this non-linear characteristic of a disc spring continues to interest engineers.1–4

Load–displacement formula for a coned disc spring or a non-slotted disc spring was first developed by Almen and Laszlo.1,5 Based on the theory of Almen, the dimensions used to define the geometries refer to the middle line of the disc spring cross-section. The same dimensions were also used by Schremmer6 as an attempt to propose a new formula for a limited straight slotted disc spring. In comparison to the SAE formula,7 the dimensions of a disc spring simply refer to the edges of the disc spring cross-section. This is more practical for spring manufacturers to precisely work with the measurement.

A modified coned disc spring with a number of lever arm segments is known as a slotted disc spring. These two segments were clearly described by Schremmer6 and Shen and Fang3 where the extension of the Almen’s formula was employed. In the extended formula, the rigid displacement is not the only criteria included, but also the bending displacement.3,6 The existence of lever arm segments significantly contributes to the bending deflection besides allowing for the rigid rotational motion.

As pointed out in previous research,3,6,7 the load–displacement formula for the slotted disc spring was derived from a coned disc spring formula. However, the formula is geometrically limited to a straight slotted disc spring. It is numerically impractical to employ the formula for a slotted disc spring that has a number of arranged bended slots. This spring is referred to as a bended slotted disc spring in the following sections.

In this study, a newly proposed load–displacement formula in the form of energy method is systematically developed. The proposed calculations can also be used for a straight slotted disc and a single coned one.

Since the newly proposed formula is derived from the theory of Almen, similar assumptions are used and limited to a coned disc spring which are as follows1,2: (a) angular deflection of the cross-section is relatively small, (b) cross-section remains undistorted in the deflection position, and (c) the loading and support are uniformly distributed. Using these assumptions, energy method is employed as an attempt to predict the load–displacement relation for a coned disc spring.

sec.title: Derivation of a newly proposed general equation for a slotted disc spring
sec.p:
The notations for the proposed energy method are shown in Figs 4 to 6. In this method, a virtual force F3 is introduced, which acts at the top point on the middle line of the coned segment cross-section. Similar to the Almen’s assumptions, this point undergoes a rigid rotation through rotation θ. The whole rigid body of the slotted disc spring is also loaded by the force F1 and thus undergoes similar rigid rotation. To propose a new formula for a slotted disc spring, it is assumed that the energy required to allow downward vertical displacement for a coned segment is equal to the total energy that allows the downward vertical displacement of the overall spring. The slotted segments act as a rigid extension of the coned segment and thus does not deform at all during the rigid rotation. As a result, all the energy is stored in the coned portion of the spring. This assumption is graphically shown in Figure 7 where the total area of F3dδ3 that defines the required energy in the coned segment is equal to the area representing the overall disc segments F1dδ1. Using the proposed energy method, F1 and δ1 can be calculated, which are required to plot the load–displacement curve. Figure 4.

sec.title: Additional bending displacement
sec.p: A bending deflection is ignored in equations (6) to (18), which satisfies the Almen’s assumptions. As mentioned in the previous section, these assumptions are only limited to a coned disc spring where only rigid motion is allowed. Without bending, the above-proposed equations (15) and (16) and equations (17) and (18) can only be used for a coned disc spring F3 = f(δ3) using the notation as shown in Figure 4.

sec.title: Finite element models
sec.p: To validate the two-dimensional (2D) proposed computations, three-dimensional (3D) finite element analyses were carried out. Previous research5,8,9 has not established any numerical equations that can approximately satisfy the finite element analyses.

Since all the numerical equations were defined based on the non-linear elastic behavior, the finite element analyses were also performed using the non-linear elastic analyses. Unlike Bagavathiperumal and Manivasagam,9 elastic plastic analyses were not performed here since plastic deformation or material non-linearity was not computed in the numerical equations. Hex-dominant elements were used and similar boundary conditions as in Bagavathiperumal and Manivasagam9 were considered in the finite element analyses using quarter symmetrical models. All types of disc springs were supported at the bottom lines of the finite element models by allowing deflection in the radial direction. At the supporting point, no friction was considered. All disc springs were uniformly loaded at the top lines of the finite element models in the vertical direction, as shown in Figure 10. The computations were carried out using commercial package ANSYS WORKBENCH with 0.8 element size. Figure 10.
Disc spring finite element analyses: (a) coned disc spring (11861 nodes and 2016 Hex Dominant element), (b) straight slotted disc spring (35223 nodes and 7427 Hex element), and (c) bended slotted disc spring (35223 nodes and 7427 Hex element).

The calculated load–displacement curves for the three cases are shown in Figs 11 to 13. The calculated load–displacement curves using the theory of Almen and the proposed energy method are similar. This is because the proposed energy method is based on the theory of Almen. This basic result is important as a reference to propose a new formula for a straight slotted disc spring and a bended one. In the same figures, there is a slight difference between the load–displacement curves plotted using the theory of Almen and the SAE. This can be clearly explained by the different referred dimensions between the theory of Almen and the SAE.

The results of the finite element analyses results are close to those of the three numerical calculations in the early displacement but tend to deviate in the further displacement region. These trends are similar to the results obtained in the previous research.5,8,9 One possible explanation is that the radial deflection was allowed in the 3D finite element analyses. However, such deflection was ignored in the 2D computations. As a result, approximately 8–10% error is observed between the results of finite element analyses and the proposed energy method in the further displacement region.

The differences in the referred dimensions and boundary conditions clearly contribute to the error between the results of the proposed energy method and the finite element analyses. In the finite element analyses, the 3D models were uniformly loaded at the top lines of the thickness cross-sections. These boundary conditions were different in the calculations using the theory of Almen and the proposed numerical formula where the applied loads were defined at the top of the middle line of the thickness cross-sections. In the finite element analyses, the disc springs were supported at the bottom lines of the thickness cross-sections. The finite element analyses were also slightly affected by the bending deflection where it was fully ignored in the Almen’s assumptions. Based on the theory of Almen, a number of approximations were also used for small angle parameters1 besides ignoring the radial displacement which was allowed in the 3D finite element analyses.8 These factors explain the error that occurred between the results of two numerical calculations and the finite element analyses.

Since the main objective of this study is to propose a new prediction formula based on the theory of Almen, slight error contributions between the results of the finite element analyses and the numerical calculations are deferred for future work.

The load–displacement curves for a straight slotted disc spring are shown in Figure 14. Similar trends are observed. The results of the finite element analyses agree well those of with the SAE and the proposed energy method computations in the early displacement, but tend to deviate in the further displacement region. Even though bending deflection is considered in the SAE7 and the proposed energy method computations, there is still approximately 8–10% error between the finite element analyses and the two numerical calculations. These trends are similar to the results obtained for the coned disc spring as discussed in the previous section. Figure 14.

The slight error between the results of the SAE and the proposed energy method computations can be explained by the differences in referred dimensions between the proposed energy and the SAE.

Based on the similar trends of non-linear load–displacement curves between coned disc spring and a straight slotted disc spring, similar trends of a non-linear load–displacement relations can be expected for a bended slotted disc spring.

sec.title: Bended slotted disc spring load–displacement curves
sec.p: In this section, the proposed energy method was used for a bended slotted disc spring. This was performed by varying the angle between the coned disc and the lever arm segments. The heights of the lever arm segments were also purposely increased with constant inner diameter d0 which allowed these segments to be bended upwards.

Using the previous dimensions of a straight slotted disc spring, some of the geometries were then modified, as shown in Figure 15. For case A, the original straight cross-section of a slotted disc spring was modified by varying the angle β with constant length of the initial lever arm segments. The angle β between the coned and the lever arm segments was varied from its initial β = 0° in 5° increments. For case B, the value of inner diameter di was constant but the vertical slot length was purposely varied. The height of the top middle line lever segment was increased from its initial h = 0 in 2 mm increments. These were done to geometrically restructure the cross-section of the straight slotted disc spring. The remaining parameters such as slot number m and material properties elastic modulus E and Poisson ratio µ were found to be similar to the previous examples. Figure 15.
Tuning the slope angle: (a) angle variation and (b) height variation.

By employing the proposed energy method, the calculated results were compared to the finite element analyses. Similar to the previous results, approximately 8–10% error is observed between the results of the finite element analyses and the proposed energy method calculations in the further displacement region for both cases A and B. This is because of the assumptions given by the theory of Almen in the proposed energy method. A significant changing trend of load–displacement curves can also be observed in the two cases. For case A, the non-linear curves tend to change in the early displacement region, as shown in Figs 16 and 17. Unlike case A, the changing trend is different for case B where it tends to occur once the displacement reaches the maximum height of the coned segment as shown in Figs 18 and 19. These trends are important as reference for future design purposes. Figure 16.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
A new numerical formula for a bended slotted disc spring is presented based on the theory of Almen. The developed prediction formula in the form of energy method is proposed to further improve the available load–displacement equations for a disc spring. The calculated load–displacement results show the effectiveness of the proposed formula. Based on our study, some key conclusions can be summarized as follows.
For a coned disc spring, the proposed energy method is based on the Almen’s assumptions. Thus, the calculated results using the theory of Almen and the proposed method are the same. However, a small error can be clearly observed in the result comparison between the proposed energy and the finite element analyses. This error is not because of the weakness of the proposed energy method, but because of the limitations of the Almen’s assumptions. Neglecting the radial deflection, limited 2D numerical calculations are identified as factors that contribute to this error.
The proposed method has improved the limitation of the SAE straight slotted disc spring prediction formula. New calculations using the proposed angle γ can be used to solve this limitation. With the existence of angle γ, significant bended angle (γ > 0) of a bended slotted disc spring can be numerically considered. Not only that, if γ = 0, a load–displacement for a straight slotted disc spring can also be predicted.
The proposed calculations predict good non-linear load–displacement results for a bended slotted disc spring and agree well with the finite element analyses. This can be validated by the comparison to the 3D finite element analyses with small error, around 8–10%.
The calculated non-linear trends using the proposed energy method is important as a future disc spring design data bases, especially in producing bended slotted disc springs.
